moves.1... d6: This response isn't all that common and there is very little variation in what you see.
moves.2... g6: My opponent decides to go into the modern defense.
moves.3. Nc3 Bg7 4. Nf3 Nf6 5. Bg5: Normally one would play e4 but I wanted to get the bishop outside of the pawn chain so I would have the option of e3.
moves.5... O-O 6. e4: Though Bg5 is not often seen in the modern defense, it is a typical position for it. I'm fully willing to play into his book.
moves.6... Nh5: ? Breaking the pin but taking the knight out of the center. I immediatly see the opporutnity to capture there with the light bishop and after the exchange taking the pawn.
moves.7. Be2: I set my idea in motion. Also in my head is to push one of my pawns.
moves.7... Nd7: He realizes this and protects c5 and e5. However this blocks in the light bishop.
moves.8. Be3: Avoiding a threat on f6 and helping attack c5.
moves.8... b6: Defending c5 and planning to fianchetto the bishop.
moves.9. d5: Pushing the pawn that the knight doesn't attack.
moves.9... Nhf6: Breaking the rule of not moving the same piece twice in the opening. Perhaps he feared an e5 pawn push, this was the last of the three pawns I was going to push.
moves.10. O-O Ng4 11. Bd4: I would rather trade off bishops and place my knight on a strong square.
moves.11... Nge5 12. Nxe5 Nxe5 13. f4: I normally hate pushing my king pawns but I can control the center this way, restrict the knight, and trade off bishops.
moves.13... Nd7 14. Bxg7 Kxg7: I trade off bishops like I wanted to, this opens up his king early and I plan of taking advantage of that. I already envision my queen wreaking havoc in the center on d4.
moves.15. Bg4: I launch my kingside attack and place pressure and further restriction on Black's light bishop.
moves.15... Nf6 16. Bxc8: ? Breaking the rule of not trading a good bishop for a poor one. This will serve me well on my assault of f7.
moves.16... Qxc8 17. e5: The assault gains momentum and starts to get dangerous. I plan to remove the knight from protection and free up the f file.
moves.17... dxe5 18. fxe5 Nd7 19. Qd4: Threatening a discovered check with e6! and Black loses his knight.
moves.19... Kg8 20. e6: I play it anyway, placing pressure on both the knight and f7. This move will be key to my assualt.
moves.20... Nf6: Blocking off my assault on f7. Better than fxe6 dxe6 with even more attacking opportunities for White.
moves.21. Rae1: I plan to trade off knights.
moves.22. Ne4 Nxe4 23. exf7+: !! The attack comes to fruition and the kingside is destroyed.
moves.23... Rxf7 24. Rxf7 Kxf7 25. Qxe4: Threatening e7 and maintaining the option of Rf! .
moves.25... c5: Black must sacrifice the c pawn to protect the much more important e pawn. I will use this as insurance later.
moves.28... Rc8: Trying to take away my insurance pawn that makes simplifying unappealing to my opponent.
moves.29. Rf7+ Kh6: The best move, Kh8 is met by 30.Rxe7 Qxc6 31.Qf7 Rg8 32.Qxh7#
moves.30. Qe3+ Kh5 31. Rxh7+ Kg4 32. Qf3+ Kg5: The last three moves for black were forced and the culmination of my attack was to come on the next move.
moves.33. h4#: I felt that this game was one of my best legitimate attacking games ever and I was never concerned. Completly confortable and satisfying victory.
